Comment: I open with e4 quite often, as I like open games and love playing the King's Gambit in blitz games here on GameKnot.
Okay, my opponent decides to play Alekhine's defence, no open game.
Provoking another knight move.
Establishes a strong pawn center...
Establishes a strong pawn center...
...which Black will usually try to smash up as soon as possible.
Okay, time to provoke another knight move.
The four pawns attack suits my taste. Unfortunately, my decent opening theory knowledge ends at this point. I guess it's time to develop some minor pieces!
The four pawns attack suits my taste. Unfortunately, my decent opening theory knowledge ends at this point. I guess it's time to develop some minor pieces!
I was very surprised by this move as I haven't seen it before. According to the GameKnot opening database it's called the "Planinc variation".
After 6. fxg5 Black could destroy my pawn center immediately with 6... dxe5, so I decided to attack that pawn another time by developing a minor piece.
Pins my knight.

I figured out that Black should now be forced to take my knight (or retreat somewhere on the c8-h3 diagonal), otherwise his bishop is lost. I would retake with my queen, which would have a nice place on f3, attacking b7 and being on the f-file which could get very powerful after castling short, like in the King's Gambit. Furthermore, I'd own the pair of bishops.
?! Interesting, he neither takes my knight nor retreats to the queenside.
The happy bishop hunting begins! At this time I was a bit unsure of this move because it seems my King could have a hard time finding a safe place after all those pawn moves...
I should have played 9. f5 immediately, I don't know why I considered this knight move to be more important. Now Black has one last chance to save the bishop.
I should have played 9. f5 immediately, I don't know why I considered this knight move to be more important. Now Black has one last chance to save the bishop.
? Black could have saved his bishop with 9... Bxb1.
Now or never!
Defending the attack with a counter-attack. This creates the possibility to retreat to f7 after I move my knight which is attacked.
! Fortunately, the knight has a superb square on the sixth rank where it attacks the queen, so Black has no time to save the bishop.
Now taking the bishop doesn't bring in any material advantage because my knight could be taken by the queen afterwards (12. fxg6 Qxe6).
Creating a nice fork. At this point three of Black's pieces are attacked, material loss can't be avoided.
